% conv() example 
% Usage: Multiplying Causal Polynomial Sequences
    % Let X1(z) = 2 + 2z^-1 + 3z^-2 and let X2(z) = 3 + 4z^-1 + 5z^-2 + 6z^-3
    x1 = [2, 3, 4]; x2 = [2,4,3,5]; 
    x3 = conv(x1, x2);
    % X3(z) = 6 + 17z^-1 + 34z^-2 + 43z^-3 + 38z^-4 + 24z^-5

% conv_m() example 
% Usage: Multiplying Non-Causal Polynomial Sequences
    % Let X1(z) = z + 2 + 3z^-1 and let X2(z) = 2z^2 + 4z + 3 + 5z^-1
    % Notice how n range = negative of z-exponents (z^(-n))
    x1 = [1, 2, 3]; n1 = [-1:1]; x2 = [2,4,3,5]; n2 = [-2:1];
    [x3, n3] = conv_m(x1, n1, x2, n2);
    % X3(z) = 2z^3 + 8z^2 + 17z + 23 + 19z^-1 + 15z^-2

% deconv() example 
% Usage: Dividing Polynomial Sequences
    % X3(z) = 6 + 17z^-1 + 34z^-2 + 43z^-3 + 38z^-4 + 24z^-5
    x3 = [6, 17, 34, 43, 38, 24]; x1 = [2, 3, 4]; [x2, r] = deconv(x3, x1);

% residuez() example
% Usage: Inverse z-transform
% R = residues, p = poles, c = direct terms, b = numerator, a = denominator
% Rewrite X(z) in ascending powers of z^-1
    % X(z) = (z^-1) / (3 - 4z^-1 + z^-2) = (0 + z^-1) / (3 - 4z^-1 + z^-2)
    b = [0,1]; a = [3,-4,1];
    [R, p, C] = residuez(b, a);    
    [b1, a1] = residuez(R, p, c);  % Converting back to rational form
    
    % X(z) = (1 + 0.4sqrt(2)z^-1) / (1 - 0.8sqrt(2)z^-1 + 0.64z^-2)
    % AND find all the poles X(z) in the polar form to determine ROC of causal sequence
    b = [1,0.4*sqrt(2)]; a = [1, -0.8*sqrt(2), 0.64];
    [R, p, C] = residuez(b, a);
    Magnitude_poles = (abs(p))     % pole magnitudes
    Angle_poles = (angle(p))' / pi % pole angles in pi units
    % ROC = abs(z) > 0.8

% poly() example
% Usage: Computing polynomial coefficients given it's roots (Poles Multiplicity)
% Usage: inverse of roots()
    % X(z) = 1 / ((1 - 0.9z^-1)^2 * (1 + 0.9z^-1)), abs(z) > 0.9
    b=1; a = poly([0.9, 0.9, -0.9]); % compute polynomial coefficient given roots
    [R, p, C] = residuez(b, a);
